title: Correcting ocular spherical aberration with soft contact lenses.
abstract:
NoFollowing aberroscopy, aspheric front surface soft contact lenses (SCLs) were custom-made to correct spherical \ud
refractive error and ocular spherical aberration (SA) of 18 myopic and five hypermetropic subjects (age, 20.5 \ud
\ud
. 5 yr). On-eye residual aberrations, logMAR visual acuity, and contrast sensitivity were compared with the \ud
best-correcting spectacle lens, an equally powered standard SCL, and an SCL designed to be aberration free in \ud
air. Custom-made and spherical SCLs reduced SA ( p . 0.001; p . 0.05) but did not change total root-meansquare (rms) wave-front aberration (WFA). Aberration-free SCLs increased SA ( p . 0.05), coma ( p \ud
. 0.05), and total rms WFA. Visual acuity remained unchanged with any of the SCL types compared with \ud
the spectacle lens correction. Contrast sensitivity at 6 cycles/degree improved with the custom-made SCLs \ud
( p . 0.05). Increased coma with aspheric lens designs and uncorrected astigmatism limit the small possible \ud
visual benefit from correcting ocular SA with SCLs
